'Fitspiration' can create and perpetuate obsessive and disordered eating for everyone

People of colour don't owe anyone an autobiographical account of where they're "really" from

Sex or study: Do we need to sacrifice one for the other? - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/06/sexsurvey-cartoon-thumb.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Charlotte Fairclough)

Contrasting agendas must be met with compromise

In the increasingly hush-hush no man's land where the boundaries of media and law meet, home of back-room deals and cheating footballers, it has become unsurprising that headlines and stories are batted between the two factions until a mutually acceptable "truth" is agreed upon

Overseas students stand to become a monetary import

There's quite a lot of confusion over the new tuition fees scheme. One minute the government are saying you can only charge the top fee in special circumstances, next (when a high number of British universities somehow fit into the special circumstances category) they announce universities overcharging will be disciplined and finally it is suggested you will be able to buy your place at university, providing you have enough money

Overseas students stand to become a monetary import - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/06/money-cartoon-thumb.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Frances Sampayo)

Backwards reform

Improvements are usually seen as a positive step; changing the way students are taught for the better is something that everyone welcomes. However, when improvement is badly thought through - then it becomes detrimental to the course

Society silence

YUSU's Societies Committee has hardly hit the ground running. Hailed as a key part of increased representation, the golden phrase of the recent Democratic review, it now stands as an embarrassing symbol for the lack of interest and notice the student body has taken of these laboriously laid-out reforms

Aiming for autonomy

Looking at how the University's collegiate system is structured it seems entirely understandable that the College Chairs have found themselves in a position where they feel decisions are being taken without them being consulted

Students need to support motions to uphold democracy

There is no point in students voting for motions to be passed if they are unwilling to put them into practice

Students need to support motions to uphold democracy - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/06/socs-cartoon-thumb.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Samantha Strong)

Uganda must be permitted to develop

Recently, a petition swept the social networks, in opposition to a new Ugandan bill further impinging on the rights of homosexuals in that country

Summer events are a credit to the University

With the end of exams nearly upon us, people are beginning to see light at the end of the tunnel in the form of hot, lazy days lying in the garden, and drunken, exciting nights at the end of term events

Student examination methods need future reconsideration

If results are not considerably affected by open examination, perhaps there is little to be said about the use of closed exams

Free speech is a right for all

Another term, another UGM and one of the motions particularly caught my eye. As I'm sure most of you are aware, a motion was tabled to force YUSU to have a clear stance on invited speakers, and more specifically on controversial speakers

Blogs of the BNOCs

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em> reads: Blogs of the BNOCs

Prejudice pervades the National Blood Service

The National Blood Service's blanket ban on homosexual male blood donation is nothing more than thinly-veiled prejudice

University rankings are indecipherable and misleading

The arbitrary nature of University league tables emphasises how it is reputation, rather than ranking, that holds weight in the real world of employment

Will we ever overlook race?

The legacy of the Birthers poses a myriad of questions: where are we in the fight for racial equality, and how much further can we realistically eradicate what we term 'racism'?

Patronizing politics impoverishes us all

The AV campaign has highlighted how far intellectual reverse snobbery has come to define British politics

Departments should not be tempted by unethical funding

The University should support forward-thinking research rather than depending on corrupt funding

Increasing PhD led seminars will hamper undergraduates

Undergraduates and PhD students alike will suffer from inevitable department cuts, requiring more PhD students to teach seminars and tutorials

Increasing PhD led seminars will hamper undergraduates - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/05/phd-cartoon-thumb.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Sarah Jilani)

Student eviction should be the last option

Evicted is a strong word. It paints the picture of nightmare neighbours, impoverished families with crying children, and unreasonable landlords demanding rent. Think of it how you like, it's not a pleasant image

Super-injunctions leave the media suffocated by the rich

I really couldn't care less whether a premier league footballer might be having an affair with a page three girl. However, the ability of the footballer to prevent all media coverage of his illicit alliance is a provocative issue

Free LFA courses for first years are a stroke of genius

This year, Languages for All (LFA) courses were offered to first year undergraduates for free. Despite this being a positive thing, the students of York still found a way to be riled by this at the beginning of the year

Free LFA courses for first years are a stroke of genius - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/05/lfa-cartoon-thumb.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Millie Jones)

All fired up

In these turbulent political times, the revelation that the University of York, this hallowed institution of moral superiority and the high pursuit of intellect, has accepted millions in arms trade funding carries powerful impact

Invasive politics

As vital as it is for every student to use their vote wisely, recent events concerning former student, David Levene, have highlighted that politicians are always somewhat too keen to take their agendas that one step too far

Languages for abandoning

Although the University was right to waive the fee on LFA classes for first-year students at the start of the academic year, there needs to be a rethink about how the resources are distributed so that the money isn't just going to waste

Departments should not be tempted by unethical funding - Cartoon

By James Bithell

<img src="http://www.nouse.co.uk/wp-content/article_images/body/2011/05/arms-cartoon-thumb2.jpg" /> (Thumbnail credit Cartoon: Charlotte Fairclough)

Royal wedding wrongly stole focus

The UK is one of the most unequal societies in the industrialised world with four million children living in conditions of relative poverty, did you know that?
